text: Hello, everyone.
Is Beth up-- yes, OK.
It's working.
What's up, Beth?
I can hear you.

OK, so I'm so excited for Beth
and I to be here with you.

What's really interesting
is that some of you

have heard us talking about
Shared Sisterhood since way
before the book came out.

And it is really sort of
surreal because coming here
is like coming home.

And so we're here now, after
the book has been published.
It's been doing really well.
It's been winning awards.

But what we want
to do is start off

by talking about the
origin story of the book.

We're going to
just dive right in.

Beth, we're going
to take it back, OK?

Yeah, yeah, tell them
how we met, Tina.

So Beth and I have
written this book.
And we are sisters.

And we'll get into
defining that.

We're actually really
good girlfriends.

But it was not love
at first sight.

So it was at the
Academy of Management.

It's when I was
working on, actually,
weight discrimination work.
[INAUDIBLE], remember that?

I was working on
a team with Myrtle
Bell and some other folks.

And I had just presented
the paper at the Academy.

You get off the stage
and sometimes there's

a queue of people
waiting to talk to you.

And Beth skipped
up to me, for real,
legitimately skipped up to me.
And I did not know her.

And I didn't know if I
should shake her hand or call
security.
So we start talking.
And I'm very resistant.

And can I be vulnerable
with you all?
OK.
I didn't trust Beth.
I've been in multiple careers.

I've been in banking,
consulting, and in the academy.

And in each of those domains
I've been stabbed in the back
by white women.

So when Beth skipped
up to me, I didn't

know if she was coming
to help me or hurt me.

I didn't know if she was
coming to assist me or steal
my academic ideas.
I had no idea.
But Beth was really friendly.

Beth, do you want to
take it over from there?

Well, you're free to talk about
how friendly I am all you want.

But there probably
was, back then,
actual skipping involved, too.

I know you're a little hyperbole
but probably not that much
in terms of how I came up.

In terms of the people
who know me in here

know that there
probably was, indeed,
skipping involved back then.
But, yeah, you're always polite.
And I think that's the thing.
It was always politeness.

But there was
definitely a resistance.
And we knew some mutual folks.
We had some mutual friends.

But at that point,
you didn't know that.
And you didn't know who I was.

And I could sense
the resistance.

But, yet, I wanted to
get to know you better.

And I wanted to get to know more
of the work that you were doing
and potentially work with you.

We were in similar stages in our
career at that point in time.

And it was something
I wanted to do.

And so I had a choice
to make at that point

in time where I could be
very defensive and say,

well, I don't understand why
she's being resistant to me.
I'm super nice.
Why doesn't she trust me?
Like why?

I would just assume,
why wouldn't you?

Or I could try to empathize
with her a little bit

and understand why she might
not trust me right off the bat.

And why I might need to
do a little bit of work
to prove myself trustworthy.

And that's not an insult to have
to prove your trustworthiness

if you're trying to build
a relationship with someone

that you want to build
a relationship with.

And I think that it
was that foundation

and us having to
work to build trust

that allowed us to build
the relationship to be
able to write a book like this.

And so what I think is really
interesting about the story,

the origin story
of Beth and I, is

that it's actually a case
study for Shared Sisterhood.
And we're going to dig into--

no pun intended
--we're going to dig

into the three critical
aspects of Shared Sisterhood.

And before we go on,
Shared Sisterhood

is what Beth and I call a
radically optimistic philosophy

on how we can actually begin to
dismantle systemic inequities.

And we wrote the book
because we really

do feel like there's stagnation
in racial and gender equity.

If you turn on the
news, when you go back

to the summer of 2020 when
George Floyd was murdered,
think about the headlines.

Think about the
way that you felt.
I felt sick to my stomach.
I went into a cave.

I did not want to
talk to anyone.

I remember we had a Shared
Sisterhood group where

we actually watched
the verdict come in

because I needed other
people who I could talk to.

I remember calling
Laura and we were--

there were so many people
I had to reach out to.

We also wanted to move from a
conversation that often focuses
on individuals to systems.
Look, implicit bias is great.
That's fabulous.

But you could eradicate implicit
bias at the individual level

and you would still
have systemic racism.

And I know I'm speaking
to a room full of people
who know that.

But, unfortunately, in
many of the organizations

that we consult with, many
of the students who we teach,
they do not get that.

They want to stay at the
individual level of analysis.

And I think it's because
when you do that,

you don't actually
have to address power.
Power is critical.

And Shared Sisterhood
is designed to do that.

Beth, do you want to speak
about radical optimism?
Yeah, I do.

And I want to just
say one point to that

moving from individuals to
systems, we as researchers

in management and
organizational behavior

and having the background that
we do, we talk about this stuff
all the time.
We talk about mezzo-level stuff.

We talk about the way
you aggregate outcomes

from individuals to systems
and the theory behind that.

And that was missing in a
lot of the conversations,

the lay conversations on DEI and
on solving this problem that we

heard, which was a lot of
"change hearts and minds."

And a lot of, well,
hearts and minds

don't matter, just
change systems.

And Tina and I said,
well, why not both?

What if we could get people
to the systemic change

from their individual hearts
and minds of systemic change

through the relationships
with other people?

And we felt that that
was what was missing,
this connection with others.

And one thing that Tina
and I realized very early

on in our relationship
was that we
shared this radical optimism.

And what we mean by that is, we
feel like we can change things.

We feel like we
can create change.

And it's that
optimism, that feeling

that we can do something,
that moves us and drives

us to try to find, not the
solution, but a solution.

Something that can help improve
something for some people.

And we also recognize, though,
that to be optimistic like that
is a choice.

And it is sometimes a
radical choice because--

again, back to what
Tina said --because

of what we see all
the time, because

of the real world, the
realism that surrounds us.

And so we wanted
to write this book

because we were tired of waiting
for other people to write it.

And I think that's
a lesson for us all.

When you're waiting for other
people to write the thing,
don't.

And we decided to step into
that breach and do it together

and do the hard
thing to try to say,

here's our theory
behind how we can

get from changing individual
hearts and minds to changing

systems through
building relationships

with people who are different
from ourselves, which gets us
to what Shared Sisterhood is.

Actually, Tina, talk about where
you came up with that term.

And then we'll go into what
the processes are, if you will.

Well, actually,
Shared Sisterhood,

there was Bernardo
Ferdman-- is he here?
--Stacey Blake-Beard.
So we were at a PDW.

And I was actually asked
to put flesh on the term.
There was a discussion about it.

So someone had said
Shared Sisterhood.
I was like, let me take that.
Let me run with it.

So it started with me at work
coming up with fleshing it out.

I'm married to a historian,
Frederick Douglass Opie.

And I was at home, trying to
figure out, why is it that--

and, initially, it
was [? a me ?] search.

Why is it that Black and white
women have not come together?

If feminism is real, why are
we so segregated at work?
Why don't we help each other?

So I read history, looked
at labor economics,

and I realized, hey,
I realized that there

was a lack of many
things, trust being one
of the critical ingredients.

Understanding being one of
the critical ingredients,
empathy being another one.

And then I wanted to understand
what would be necessary--

what would be a necessary
process to rectify that?

And I realized, and
Beth and I actually

had some debate,
because there was a need

to address, as Beth said, hearts
and minds, but also systems.

And I know some
people will push back.

They're like, I don't care
what you really think about me.

If you like me, just
put it in a policy.

But I think we have seen what
can happen with policies alone.

I think we've seen what happens
when we try to only address
hearts and minds.

You need both, I believe,
to have the best outcomes.

Beth, do you want
to add anything?

No, I think I was
fortunate enough

that we started talking about
this over five years ago now.

And I think when you're talking
about building relationships,

and one of the things
we know in academia

is sometimes the best ideas
come via collaboration.

And Tina said to write about
sisterhood, I need a sister.

And so we came together to
write about the three components
of Shared Sisterhood.

And so Tina has started to talk
a little bit about the dig,
which is the hearts and minds.
How do you do that?

So I'll just talk a
little bit about that.

And then, Tina, if you want
to talk about bridge after I'm
done with dig, sound good?

Actually, I want to
talk about digging.
Let's switch it.

OK,
[INTERPOSING VOICES]
Let's [INAUDIBLE] that.
OK, go ahead.
Yeah, yeah.

Because I think when
Beth skipped up to me,

you have an illustration
in your head, I had to dig.

And dig is about surfacing your
own assumptions, your beliefs.

I was like, what is
this white girl doing?
I don't trust her.
But I had to ask myself.
I had to dig.

Has she done anything
to demonstrate
herself to be untrustworthy?
The answer was no.
So what's up, Tina?
Why don't you trust her?

I had to go through the fact
that I had been back stabbed
by so many white women.

And then I realized, I
wasn't individuating.

I was processing Beth as a
proxy for all white women,
which is not fair.

So then I had to
challenge myself.
I had to dig.

There was so much
unpacking to do.

And what I want you to recognize
is, in Shared Sisterhood
we address the issue of power.

And we define power as control
over an access to resources,

time, money, people, the ability
to control whose history is

studied or not, what books get
banned or not, that is power.

Historically there
are some people groups

who've had access to
power, white people, men,

heterosexual people, Christian
people, tall people, fit
people.

And, historically, there
have been some groups--

and that's just examples
--historically there

have been some groups that
have been more marginalized,

Black people, Latinx people,
gay people, Muslim people,
atheist people.

When Beth and I
were interacting I

was primarily assessing
her on the axis
of whiteness and Blackness.

As we got to know each other,
which she'll talk about

in bridge, I came to realize
we have many things in common.
Beth is an atheist.
I'm a Christian.

So there's a power
difference there.

But if I hadn't
done the dig work,

I never would have
gotten to know that.

And I would have missed out on
a really beautiful relationship.

The final thing I'll say
is that while it was unfair

that I processed Beth as a
proxy for all white people,
it was absolutely adaptive.

And if we switch to
the example of gender,
how many women in the room--

or let me say this --how many
people who do not identify
as men--

if you go out,
it's late at night.
You push 9 and 1 on your phone.

And you hover your
finger over the last 1,

just in case some joker
jumps out from the alley.

How many of you have put your
keys between your fingers

in case you need to jab
somebody in the eye?

Does that mean that
you hate all men?
It's not a rhetorical question.

Does that mean that
you hate all men?
Why do you do that?
Statistically, what?
It could happen.

And who is likely to
be the perpetrator?
A man, sorry.

White people,
statistically speaking,

while the media would have you
believe that I'm the threat,

most violence towards Black
people comes from you.
It's not the other way around.

In the workplace, that is
the way that it happens.

But I still had to
recognize that while that

was adaptive and protective, if
I did not take that armor down

it would not have allowed
sun and water to get to me

to foster the relationship
that Beth and I now have.
So that's dig.

Beth, you want to
talk about bridge?

Absolutely, so
digging, and both of us

had to do our own
dig functions here.

I had to also dig in to how
I felt about how I approached

Tina and why I expected to
be trusted right off the bat

and without having to
prove myself, which
is a ridiculous assumption.
And yet one that I held.

And we all had a lot
of digging that we
had to do in different ways.

And we started at different
points of that journey

in terms of how we
understand power

and how we needed
to understand power.

But one of the
key things that we

try to add with
Shared Sisterhood
is this idea of bridge.

That in order to
get from digging

in to changing our hearts and
minds to collective action

to change systems, we have to
bridge with other people who
are different than us.

And we call bridge a form
of authentic connections

we build on the
positive psychology

conception of
high-quality connections

to talk about what these
authentic connections

with people who are
different from you are.

And we hypothesize
that they consist

of four different
things, which is

showing empathy, demonstrating
vulnerability, establishing

trust, and taking risks on
behalf of the other person

in order to help
establish those things.

And in Shared Sisterhood,
what that means is
when you interact with people--

particularly those who are
different than you --on those

axis that we were talking
about, those axis of power.

When you interact
with other people,

your interactions,
when possible,

should be authentic in that they
demonstrate these four things.

So we expect that when Tina
and I first interacted,

for instance, and started
to build a bridge,

I had to empathize with why
she was standoffish with me.

And I had to demonstrate my
vulnerability to put myself out

there to take risks, to stand
up, and say things and do

things to demonstrate
that I was trustworthy
so we could establish trust.

And in doing that,
both of us sort of had

to start from different
places in building
this authentic relationship.

Where I had to start
with empathy and she
had to start with trusting me.

And we built towards this strong
bridge, that in every time

we interacted, so long as we
were interacting authentically,

we were able to
build this bridge up.

And, importantly, and something
Tina and I always say is,
that doesn't mean--

we happen to be
really good friends.

But that doesn't mean you
have to be really good friends

because we hear a lot
from people who are like,

I don't have the energy to have
any more friends right now.
I have a lot of friends.

I don't have the
energy to have friends.

There are people
that I build bridges

with in the workplace who
I wouldn't hang out with.

I'm not going to
their house and stuff.

But I know that I can trust
that they're going to stand up
for me if I'm not in the room.

I know that I can
authentically connect with them
in those ways.

And it's those connections
that we talk about when
we talk about bridge.
Tina?
Yes.

And we have about 3
and 1/2 minutes left.
So we're going to--
We only have two more slides.
We're good.
Yeah,
OK, good, good, good.

So the final step,
which is also important,

so once you've done
dig, and you've bridged,

and you have authentic
interpersonal connections

with people, now
you're ready for

some juicy collective
action, which is where
you can link arms with people.

And we like to say that there
are at least eight core people

processes, from onboarding,
recruiting, evaluation,

training, performance,
all those things.

So the idea is that, as we build
bridges with certain people,
we bring in other connections.

And this is general
social network stuff
that we've talked about.

But it's about building these
connections authentically.

It also means that there
might be people who
don't want to bridge with me.

They're just not
interested, which
is completely fine because--
Their lost.
Thank you.

But it is OK because if
they're bridging with Tina

and I'm bridging
with Tina, we're

still able to work collectively
because we can build

this network together,
authentically,

to be able to do the work
of collective action.

Yeah, so once you have this
latticework of connections

and you link arms, you can
start with one of those people

processes that I just mentioned,
the recruiting, the onboarding,
et cetera, et cetera.

And then you want to focus
on metrics for success.

What we want to do
with collective action

is actually hold
people accountable.

And this is getting very
practitioner-focused.
Is that all right with y'all?

I know there's
practitioners in the room.
But we're also academics.

But, hey, y'all have known me
since I was a doctoral student.

I've always done this, which has
gotten me in trouble from jump.
So what we do is we make--

Shared Sisterhood is
very action oriented.

So when we talk about
collective action,

we encourage
organizations to pick

one of those people processes
and to nail that thing down.

So if you're going
to really focus

on evaluations, for example, or
salaries, pay, and promotion,

we want you to
say, I don't know.

Let's do a performance
audit or a pay audit
by gender, by race, by division.

And why don't we
figure out how we're
going to report that thing out?

Are we going to report
it out to the division?
Who's responsible?

What's the budget that
we're going to allocate
to actually correct it?

If we find
disparities, how are we
going to reconcile those things?

Are we going to actually
redress historical inequities?
That's a big issue.

When you find out that
women and Black people

have been underpaid
for 10 years,
do you just say, sorry, folks?

Or do you actually
make them whole?

Those are all of
the kinds of things

that we address
with organizations
with Shared Sisterhood.
It is actually working.

If you don't believe me, there's
a Harvard Business Review

article where we actually
provide data with organizations
we've done this with.

Beth, I will let you
have the last word.

Well, the last thing
that I will say

is the goal of this was to
move from individual hearts

and minds to collective
action towards redressing

historical inequities
in the workplace.

And we believe
one of the reasons

that Shared Sisterhood
might be a good solution

for this is because
it contrasts with more
transactional approaches.

We know you get
leaders in place who
believe this with their hearts.
And then those leaders leave.

Those policies are
only as often require

the sort of hearts and minds
changes from the leaders
to implement them.

And when you have a network of
people who have built bridges

with each other, they're able
to put a lot more pressure

on those leadership
structures to change.
And with that, we're done.

Thank you for letting me
[INAUDIBLE],, by the way.

I appreciate you all for
letting me because it's in Iowa.
You know, I'm teaching today.

Y'all know how that
is, so, thank you.
